    Disrupting Acetyl-Lysine Recognition: Progress in the Development of Bromodomain Inhibitors

    • F. Anthony Romero*†
      • , 
    • Alexander M. Taylor‡
      • , 
    • Terry D. Crawford†
      • , 
    • Vickie Tsui†
      • , 
    • Alexandre Côté‡
      • , and 
    • Steven Magnuson†
    View Author Information
    † Discovery Chemistry, Genentech, Inc. 1 DNA Way, South San Francisco, California 94080, United States
    ‡ Constellation Pharmaceuticals, Inc. 215 First Street, Suite 200, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02142, United States
    *Phone: +1-650-467-6384. E-mail: [email protected]
    Cite this: J. Med. Chem. 2016, 59, 4, 1271–1298
    Publication Date (Web):November 16, 2015

    Publication History

    • Published online1 December 2015
    • Published inissue 25 February 2016

    Get e-Alerts
    SUBJECTS:
    • Chemical structure,

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Bromodomains, small protein modules that recognize acetylated lysine on histones, play a significant role in the epigenome, where they function as “readers” that ultimately determine the functional outcome of the post-translational modification. Because the initial discovery of selective BET inhibitors have helped define the role of that protein family in oncology and inflammation, BET bromodomains have continued to garner the most attention of any other bromodomain. More recently, non-BET bromodomain inhibitors that are potent and selective have been disclosed for ATAD2, CBP, BRD7/9, BRPF, BRPF/TRIM24, CECR2, SMARCA4, and BAZ2A/B. Such novel inhibitors can be used to probe the physiological function of these non-BET bromodomains and further understanding of their role in certain disease states. Here, we provide an update to the progress in identifying selective bromodomain inhibitors and their use as biological tools, as well as our perspective on the field.

    SPECIAL ISSUE

    This article is part of the Epigenetics special issue.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    One of the most widely studied histone post-translational modification (PTM) is acetylation.(1) Histones are covalently modified at the ε-amino group of lysines by histone acetyltransferases (HATs), thereby neutralizing the positive charge and thus interfering with the histone–DNA interaction essential for nucleosome stability.(2) Since Allfrey’s discovery of histone acetylation in 1964,(3) it is now understood that the interplay of acetylation and deacetylation of chromatin plays a critical role in transcription.(1) Key to this process is the ability of “readers” to recognize specific PTMs that ultimately determine the functional outcome of the PTM.(4, 5) Three readers (bromodomain,(6, 7) double PHD finger,(8, 9) and pleckstrin homology domain)(10) that recognize acetylated lysine (KAc) have been identified and the bromodomain is the most thoroughly characterized of the three.(11)
    Bromodomains were first identified in Drosphilia (brahma gene),(12, 13) and their function remained largely unknown until it was discovered that bromodomains bind acetyl-lysine.(6) To date, 61 bromodomains have been identified, and these domains consist of roughly 110 amino acid residues.(7, 11, 14) Initially, the concept of targeting a bromodomain was thought to be challenging because it would involve inhibiting a protein–peptide interaction, but this changed in 2010 when two potent and selective bromodomain inhibitors were shown to bind in the KAc binding groove. The molecules 1 (Figure 1),(15) which was identified from an earlier Mitsubishi patent,(16) and 2 (Figure 1),(17) which was identified at GSK through phenotypic screening, were shown to inhibit the function of members of the bromodomain and extra terminal domain family (BET). This family is characterized by dual bromodomains and consists of BRD2, BRD3, BRD4, and BRDT. Since these disclosures, there has been a significant amount of work on developing BET inhibitors and on understanding the role of BET proteins in various disease states that include oncology, inflammation, immunology, and cardiovascular disease.(18, 19) While much of the focus of bromodomain inhibition research has targeted the BET family, there is now quite a bit of interest in non-BET bromodomains. This interest has culminated in recent reports describing potent and selective inhibitors that should help define the physiological role of these proteins.(7, 19-21) Literature reports related to bromodomains increased steadily from 1992 to 2010 (Figure 2).(22) After the simultaneous publication of the papers describing 1 and 2 in 2010, there was a significant increase in publications. Herein, we will describe the recent progress on both BET and non-BET bromodomain inhibitors, with an eye toward their application to understanding the physiological significance of these bromodomains.

    Structural Features of Bromodomains

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Following the trend in number of publications, bromodomain structures in the Protein Data Bank (PDB) have increased significantly in the past few years, and many of these reported structures include small molecules bound in the KAc binding site. This site is located at one end of a four-helical bundle bromodomain, away from both the C- and N-termini (Figure 3B). Acetylated-lysine and most of the known small molecule ligands form a hydrogen bond with the side chain of a conserved asparagine residue located at the beginning of the BC loop [Asn140 in the case of BRD4(1)], and a water-mediated hydrogen bond with the hydroxyl of a conserved tyrosine located on the ZA loop [Tyr97 in BRD4(1)] (Figure 3C). Deeper in the back of this binding pocket, a network of water molecules is observed that is conserved across various bromodomains. In many of the structures, this network extends to a channel framed by the ZA loop that is termed the ZA channel. The ZA channel can be used to enhance potency and selectivity, as can the adjacent region known as the “WPF shelf” in BET based on the conservation of the WPF motif in BET family members.(23) The “WPF shelf” is not a general term for non-BET bromodomains because they lack the sequence conservation. Although the phenylalanine is nearly invariant, the other two residues can vary in size, hydrophobicity, or effects on backbone conformational properties (Table 1). These differences may make the “WPF shelf” a productive area to explore to achieve selectivity depending on the desired on- and off-targets. Another important specificity determinant is the so-called “gatekeeper” residue (Table 1).(23) Located at the start of the C helix, it defines the shape of one side of the entrance into the KAc binding site. For example, the Tyr222 gatekeeper of BRD9 forms what resembles a flat floor, allowing the aromatic motifs of the three BRD9 inhibitors to π-stack with the receptor (see Figure 9 and BRD9 section for further discussion). These aromatic interactions augment the interactions seen with the conserved Asn216 and Tyr173.
    Table 1. Aligned Amino Acid Compositions for WPF Motif and Gatekeeper Residues of Selected Bromodomains
    bromodomainWPF motif residuesgatekeeper
    BRD4(1)TrpProPheIle
    BRD4(2)TrpProPheVal
    CBPLeuProPheVal
    TRIM24LeuAlaPheVal
    BRD9GlyPhePheTyr
    CECR2TrpProPheTyr
    BRPF1AsnIlePhePhe
    BRPF3HisIlePhePhe
    PCAFTrpProPheTyr
    BAZ2BTrpProPheIle
    ATAD2ArgValPheIle
    SMARCA4 (BRG1)GluValPheIle
    The growing number of publicly available bromodomain crystal structures warrants a caution in the analysis and interpretation of such structures. Most bromodomains pack in the crystal lattice such that the KAc binding sites from two asymmetric subunits are directly interacting with each other. This is not automatically displayed by most programs; however, many programs allow the generation of symmetry mates that enable the evaluation of potential artifacts due to packing interactions. An example is shown for CBP (Figure 4) in which the side chain conformation of Arg1173 wraps (cyan) around and makes π–π interactions with tetrahydroquinoline part of the ligand 4. However, examination of a neighboring symmetry mate (gray) shows that the arginine also makes multiple interactions with glutamic acids in the crystal lattice, leading one to question the biological relevance of this observed conformation or the interpretation of a ligand/Arg interaction.(24) Another example in which the ligand conformations are affected by different packing within the asymmetric subunit and between symmetry mates will be discussed in the section on TRIM24.

    CBP Bromodomain Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The cAMP response element binding protein (CREBBP, CBP, KAT3A) and a highly homologous paralogue, adenoviral E1A binding protein (EP300, p300, KAT3B), are large multidomain proteins,(25) each contain a bromodomain that has been shown to recognize p53 acetylated at K382 following DNA damage.(26) CBP and p300 have been implicated as potential oncology targets.(27-29) Recently, Liu et al. implicated p300 in cancer immunology, demonstrating that p300 is critical for Foxp3+ regulatory T cell (Treg) function and homeostasis.(30) These cells play a critical role in limiting host autoimmunity and act as master regulators of the immune system. Liu and co-workers observed a significant decrease in Foxp3+ Treg cells in p300 conditional knockout mice relative to wild-type mice, as well as significantly decreased tumor growth. While this effect was observed from knocking out the entire multidomain protein, it remained unclear whether inhibition of specific domains (e.g., the HAT domain or the bromodomain) would have the same effect. Genentech (GNE) and Constellation Pharmaceuticals (CPI) have subsequently disclosed the use of bromodomain inhibitors for cancer immunotherapy.(31) They exemplify a CBP/p300 bromodomain inhibitor that not only reduces numbers of Foxp3+ Treg cells but also reduces the expression of other immune checkpoint receptors such as LAG3, TIM3, and CTLA4. In addition, GNE and CPI disclose that similar effects are seen using a recently disclosed CBP inhibitor (compound 4; Figure 4).(24, 31) It is clear that the development of potent and selective CBP bromodomain inhibitors will help further elucidate the role of CBP in tumor immune responses and other oncology indications.
    Pioneering work toward identifying CBP inhibitors was initially reported by Zhou et al. and Hewings et al. Although compounds 5 (MS2126),(32)6 (MS7972),(32)7 (Ischemin),(33) and compound 8(34) have micromolar affinity (Figure 5), these studies set the stage for targeting the CBP bromodomain with more potent small molecule inhibitors. These early compounds have been reviewed elsewhere in detail,(19, 20) and the discussion that follows will focus on the potent and selective CBP inhibitors that have been reported after these initial disclosures.

    Structural Genomics Consortium (SGC) CBP Inhibitors

    During the course of identifying compound 8, Hewings et al. discovered that N-methyl pyrrolidinone (NMP) binds to CBP with a 2.3 mM affinity and high ligand efficiency (LE).(34) Following up on this discovery with the screening of NMP analogues, Rooney et al. identified 3-methyl-3,4-dihydroquinazolin-2(1H)-one (9, IC50 = 29.4 μM, LE = 0.51) as an attractive starting point (Figure 6).(24) They were aware that 9 was susceptible to benzylic oxidation,(34, 35) so they addressed this concern by exploring benzoxazinone- and dihydroquinoxalinone-based cores. The combination of the dihydroquinoxalinone core and optimization at the 5-position, using an amide library, led to compound 4 (IC50 = 323 nM, ITC Kd = 390 nM). This compound is the first disclosed example of a CBP inhibitor with submicromolar affinity. A co-crystal structure of compound 4 with the bromodomain of CBP revealed that the tetrahydroquinoline (THQ) moiety binds in the LPF shelf region (corresponding to the WPF shelf of BRD4; Table 1), sandwiched between Pro1110 and Arg1173. It is clear that gaining the interaction to the LPF shelf contributes significantly to its potency. Compound 4 was shown to be selective for CBP over several bromodomains, however, only moderate selectivity (4-fold) was observed for CBP over BRD4. In a cellular context using a fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP) assay (see Assessing Target Engagement/Cellular Activity section for explanation of FRAP), compound 4 was able to displace the CBP bromodomain from chromatin in U2OS cells.
    Soon after this publication, a detailed account of the development of the SGC-nominated probe 11 (SGC-CBP30) was disclosed (Figure 6).(36, 37) Earlier investigations of isoxazolylbenzimidazoles as selective BET inhibitors revealed that fragment 10(38) showed similar potency for both BRD4 (IC50 = 6.3 μM) and CBP (IC50 = 4 μM) and demonstrated the potential to add substitutents to the N-1 position of the benzimidazole for further potency optimization. Hay et al. began to explore the ZA channel by substituting at C-2 and to target the LPF shelf by introducing modifications at N-1. A crystal structure of an unoptimized compound revealed a flipped binding mode in which the substituents in the C-2 position were directed to the LPF shelf, and substituents at the N-2 position were interacting with the ZA channel. Further optimization unveiled 11 (IC50 = 69 nM, ITC Kd = 21 nM). Co-crystallization of 11 with the CBP bromodomain showed that the chlorophenyl ring interacts with Arg1173 in a manner similar to the interaction of the THQ ring of compound 4. Selectivity of 11 over non-BET bromodomains was good, and moderate selectivity was obtained over BRD4 (40-fold), an improvement of 10-fold compared to compound 4. The utility of this compound was examined in FRAP and p53 luciferase reporter assays. Compound 11 inhibited p53 activity with an IC50 of 1.5 μM. Recently Hammitzsh et al. found that 11 suppresses human Th17 responses.(39) While pan-BET inhibitors elicit a similar phenotype with broad effects on gene expression, 11 was shown to have a more narrow effect. This indicates that CBP inhibitors have the potential to have more nuanced therapeutic effects than BET inhibitors. In vitro ADME suggested that 11 would not be effective as an in vivo probe, and undoubtedly a compound that could be tested in vivo would be very helpful in clarifying the potential of therapeutic targeting of CBP.
    Another CBP probe, 12(40) (I-CBP112, IC50 = 170 nM, ITC Kd = 151 nM), has been released on the SGC web site, but the detailed optimization of this compound has not been disclosed (Figure 6). This probe has a unique benzoxazepine core with the carbonyl of the ethylamide binding Asn1168, the piperidine binding in the BC loop and the diemethoxy phenyl positioned over the LPF shelf (PDB: 4NR6). This compound is the first of the CBP inhibitors to have a group binding in the BC loop region, where the piperidine mostly points out to solvent. As noted above, the importance of the “WPF shelf” (or LPF shelf in this case) is a common theme among bromodomain inhibitors; this region appears to play an important role for 12, in that important interactions are observed with the dimethoxyphenyl sandwiched between Pro1110 and Arg1173. This hydrophobic shelf appears to be critical not only for potency but also for selectivity against other bromodomains, and it is often different among the various bromodomains, as described above (Table 1). In the FRAP assay, 12 accelerated fluorescence recovery at 1 μM. Good selectivity was reported in a BLI assay against several bromodomains, although the SGC Web site does disclose that weak cross-reactivity was only noted for the BET family.

    University of Zurich CBP Inhibitors

    Recently, Nevado and Caflisch and co-workers have published back-to-back papers describing their work on identifying potent and selective CBP inhibitors.(41, 42) Using an in silico approach, the authors identified an acyl benzamide (Kd = 29 μM, LE = 0.27) as a hit. Structurally similar analogues were purchased and screened that resulted in the identification of compound 13 (Kd = 5 μM, LE = 0.36) as a more efficient starting point (Figure 6). Modeling suggested the fumaric acid interacted with Arg1173. In pursuit of optimizing this area, the fumaric acid side chain was replaced with a benzoic acid, which resulted in a 6-fold increase in potency. Further substitution on the benzoic acid moiety led to compounds 14 (Kd = 170 nM, ITC Kd = 300 nM) and 15 (Kd = 400 nM, Figure 6). Selectivity was measured against several of the BET family members and each compound showed moderate selectivity for CBP. In the BRD4(1) assay compound 14 showed a potency of ∼10 μM, providing a 60-fold selectivity window. The methyl ester of compound 15 was found to have low micromolar GI50 values against ML2 and MOLM-13 cell lines. These results may indicate a path forward for CBP inhibitors to treat acute myeloid leukemia.
    Since the initial discovery of early CBP inhibitors by Zhou et al., there has been much progress in identifying potent and selective inhibitors. It is clear that starting from ligand-efficient fragments can readily yield nanomolar inhibitors. The SGC and others have made significant progress in developing potent and selective CBP inhibitors, but it remains to be seen if lack of high selectivity over BET bromodomains will confound results when trying to isolate the role of CBP. Inhibition of the BET family bromodomains produces pronounced phenotypes, and there is little shift in cellular potency from the measured biochemical IC50s against BRD4 (representative BET BRD).(43, 44) Although 60-fold or even 100-fold biochemical selectivity appears reasonable, this still may not be enough to tease apart CBP-associated phenotypes from those of BET inhibition. One of the key struggles going forward in this field is identifying potent and selective CBP inhibitors devoid of BET activity, in addition to the challenge mentioned above of identifying a probe suitable for in vivo studies.

    BAZ2A/B Bromodomain Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Little is known about the function of BAZ2A/B (bromodomain adjacent to zinc finger domain, 2A/B), although it is known to be a member of the nuclear remodeling complex (NoRC).(45) Elevated expression levels of BAZ2A have been observed in prostate cancer,(46) which has sparked interest in the development of probe compounds for use a chemical genetic tools.

    SGC BAZ2A/B Inhibitors

    The SGC has recently published two papers describing BAZ2A/B inhibitors. Drouin et al. reported the first BAZ2A/B inhibitor 16 (BAZ-ICR, Figure 7).(47) Virtual screening of putative bromodomain inhibitors led to the discovery of this trisubstituted imidazole scaffold. The crystal structure of compound 16 bound to BAZ2B shows that the N-methyl pyrazole, directly attached to the central imidazole, serves as the KAc mimetic. Interestingly, the pendant ethyl-linked electron rich N-methyl pyrazole folds back to form an intramolecular π-stacking interaction with the electron-poor benzonitrile. In addition, the nitrile also forms a hydrogen bond to Leu1891 while the pyrazole hydrogen bonds to Asn1894. Compound 16 showed moderate potency (ITC BAZ2A/BAZ2B Kds of 110 and 170 nM) while displaying good selectivity when assayed against a broad panel of 47 bromodomains, with the lone exception of CECR2 (ITC Kd = 1.55 μM). Compound 16 also showed cellular activity in a FRAP assay.
    The second BAZ2A/B probe from the SGC that was developed by GlaxoSmithKline (GSK), 17 (GSK2801, Figure 7), evolved from a hit containing a keto-indolizine in which the methyl ketone functions as the KAc mimetic.(48) Incorporation of an ortho-methyl sulfone on the phenyl ring attached to the indolizine core induces a nonplanar orientation of the two rings that is well tolerated by BAZ2B but not by BRD2 due to the smaller binding pocket dimensions of the latter bromodomain. The propyl ether on the other side of the core reaches into the ZA/BC pocket, providing a small increase in potency and apparently imparting selectivity over BRD9 based on AlphaScreen data (BRD9 IC50 > 50 μM vs 24 μM without the propyl ether). Subsequent ITC analysis, however, indicated the selectivity window of 17 was narrower than originally observed in the AlphaScreen (BAZ2A/BAZ2B ITC Kds of 260 and 140 nM, BRD9 ITC Kd of 1.1 μM). While 17 may not have ideal selectivity for phenotypic screening, it provides an alternate scaffold to 16 and is therefore potentially highly useful by comparison with 16 in identifying true on-target effects. Also, because the selective BRD7/9 inhibitor 22 is derived from the same scaffold as 17, compound 22 provides an opportunity to identify any confounding BRD7/9-driven phenotypes.

    BRD7/9 Bromodomain Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The function of BRD9 (bromodomain-containing protein 9) is unknown, although its overexpression has been associated with several disease areas, including cervical cancers and nonsmall cell lung cancer.(49, 50) Interestingly, proteomic analysis has identified BRD9 as a subunit in the mammalian BAF SWI/SNF complex.(51, 52) In contrast, the highly similar bromodomain-containing protein 7 (BRD7) is a subunit of the PBAF SWI/SNF complex,(51, 53) and may play a role in recruiting specific transcription factors.(54) It has been proposed that BRD7 is a tumor suppressor and, accordingly, BRD7 has been found to be down-regulated in cancer cells.(55)

    SGC BRD7/9 Inhibitors

    The SGC previously reported nonselective BRD9 inhibitors,(56, 57) and the utility of these compounds in phenotypic studies was limited by their binding to BET bromodomains. Since the initial reports, these authors have identified three distinct potent and selective BRD7/9 dual inhibitors. The first of these selective inhibitors that was developed by the University of Oxford, 20 (LP99, Figure 8), was derived from 1-methylquinolone (18).(58) The N-methyl pyridone served as the KAc mimetic, forming a single hydrogen bond to the conserved Asn106, while the quinolone core forms a π-stacking interaction with the Tyr106 gatekeeper. Addition of a valerolactam directed into the hydrophobic ZA channel enabled a scaffold that could be further substituted to interact with the active site. Investigation of substitution on the valerolactam yielded 19 (ITC Kd = 493 nM, Figure 8). A crystal structure of 19 bound to BRD9 revealed that the phenyl moiety was oriented into the hydrophobic pocket of BRD9 (Figure 9A). Further optimization of substitution on the phenyl ring of 19 resulted in 20 (ITC Kd = 99 nM). Compound 20 was found to be selective against a panel of 48 bromodomians, with only BRD9 and paralogue BRD7 showing significant binding when assayed by DSF in the presence of 10 μM compound.
    The second SGC probe, compound 22 (Figure 8), utilized the keto-indolizine scaffold that was first incorporated in the BAZ2A/B chemical probe 17.(59) As observed with BAZ2A/B, the ketone forms the necessary hydrogen bonding interaction with Asn100 (Figure 9B). The binding is further strengthened by a π-stacking interaction between the indolizine core and Tyr106 and possibly by a second interaction to the Asn100 through a nonclassical hydrogen bond interaction between the asparagine carbonyl and hydrogen at the indolizine C7 position. Hay et al. placed a 2-pyridyl at the 1-position of the indolizine, yielding 21, a compound with BRD9 activity and equivalent BAZ2B activity as measured by an AlphaScreen assay. Subsequent conversion of the pyridine to an imidazo[1,2-a]pyridine and incorporation of a morpholine at the 7-position afforded compound 22. This compound retained BRD9 affinity (DSF ΔTm 4.5 °C, IC50 = 126 nM, ITC Kd = 68 nM), demonstrated selectivity against other bromodomain family members, including BAZ2A/B, and showed activity in a FRAP cellular assay (1 μM).
    Lastly, the SGC Web site has been updated with a new chemical probe for BRD7/9, BI-9564, that was developed by Boehringer-Ingelheim.(60) The structure is not yet disclosed, but it is noted that the compound was discovered through fragment-based screening and optimization. BI-9564 binds to BRD9 and BRD7 with Kd values of 14 and 239 nM, respectively, as measured by ITC. Interestingly, the affinities for BET bromodomains are reported to be >100 μM. In addition, BI-9564 is reported to have cellular activity in a FRAP assay (1 μM). There does appear to be some off-target binding to CECR2 (ITC Kd = 258 nM), but this does not translate into the cellular setting.

    GlaxoSmithKline BRD9 Inhibitor

    Theodoulou et al. from GSK identified 24 (I-BRD9, Figure 8), a broadly selective BRD9 inhibitor that is, to date, the only published tool compound published with significant selectivity for BRD9 over BRD7.(61) The initial thienopyridone scaffold (23) was identified through screening of internal GSK compounds with the N-methyl pyridone functioning as the KAc mimetic. BRD4 selectivity was improved upon through the introduction of an amidine group at the 2-position of the thienopyridone core (Figure 9C). This appendage makes a direct hydrogen bond to the Ile53 of BRD9 that mitigates the potential offending carbonyl–carbonyl interaction observed between Ile53 and the amide of 23, increasing BRD9 potency, while the authors hypothesize that the amidine is less tolerated in the more hydrophobic pocket of BRD4. Also contributing to overall selectivity was the electron-deficient m-trifluoromethylbenzene that fills the ZA channel, as well as increasing steric bulk of the pyridone by replacing the N-methyl substituent with N-ethyl. This optimization yielded 24 (IC50 = 50 nM) that is selective over BRD4 (IC50 = 5,000 nM). Selectivity was further assessed by BROMOscan screening, and the results showed that 24 is >200-fold selective for BRD9 (Kd = 2 nM) over BRD7 (Kd = 398 nM), a surprising result given the high degree of homology between the two paralogues. The authors provide a rationale for the BRD7/9 selectivity that is based on rather conservative residue differences. In BRD9, GPP shelf Gly43 (Table 1) and ZA channel Ala46 create a slightly larger pocket compared to their BRD7 equivalent Ala154 and Ser157, allowing an optimal fit of the inhibitor to the binding pocket of BRD9. The selectivity over BRD7 allows investigators to explore the phenotypic effects of BRD9 inhibitors without contamination from BRD7 inhibition.
    The phenotypic effects of either dual BRD7/9 or BRD9 inhibitors have proven intriguing. Scientists at GSK studied the gene expression changes induced by 24 along with a BET inhibitor and found that genes such as CLEC1, FES, SAMSN1, and DUSP6 were selectively and strongly down-regulated by the BRD9 inhibitor. These genes have been implicated in cancer and immunological pathways. Compound 20 was found to inhibit the secretion of IL-6 from cultured THP-1 cells, and a patent application by Genentech and Constellation disclosed that the inhibition of BRD7/9 bromodomains (structures not disclosed) results in inhibition of IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 production by human Th2 cells.(62) The reduction of these cytokines suggests BRD7/9 bromodomain inhibitors may have a role in treatment of inflammatory conditions.

    ATAD2 Bromodomain Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    ATAD2 (ATPase family, AAA domain containing 2) is overexpressed in a wide variety of cancers, including prostate and triple-negative breast.(63, 64) Interestingly, ATAD2 binds the MYC protein, stimulates MYC-dependent transcriptional activity and may contribute to the development of aggressive cancers.(65) It has been suggested that inhibitors of ATAD2 could be novel oncology treatments, although the specific role of the bromodomain in ATAD2 function is currently unclear.

    GlaxoSmithKline ATAD2 Inhibitor

    While there is interest in the biological function of ATAD2, the ATAD2 bromodomain is considered one of the most difficult-to-drug members of the family.(66) Compared to other bromodomains, the ATAD2 pocket is quite shallow. This suggests that gaining selectivity for ATAD2 over other bromodomains would be a significant challenge. Harner et al. disclosed NMR fragment screen hits that bound to ATAD2 with Kds ranging from 350–600 μM and with ligand efficiencies ranging from 0.25–0.32.(67) Not surprisingly, the most efficient fragments were from scaffolds that are also found among strong binders to other bromodomains. A single-digit micromolar ATAD2 inhibitor (26, IC50 = 1.3 μM, LE = 0.30, Figure 10) based on a 3-methylquinolinone fragment hit (25) was recently reported by Demont et al.(68) Key to optimization of 25 was replacing the flexible dimethylamino ethyl with a 4-aminopiperidine, providing a rigidified conformation to interact with Asp1071, as well as incorporating a 3-pyridyl ring that forms a direct hydrogen bond to Asp1014. Compound 26 was moderately potent against ATAD2 but had equivalent affinity for BET bromodomains. In a recent follow-up paper, Bamborough et al. focused on increasing ATAD2 potency while decreasing BRD4 potency.(69) The authors surmised that targeting the more polar and flexible RVF shelf in ATAD2 (Arg1007, Val1008, and Phe1009) might be productive in gaining both potency and selectivity over BRD4, which has a more hydrophobic WPF shelf. Substitution at C3 of the piperidine allowed access to the RVF shelf. Optimization in this area led to ether-linked cyclic sulfone 27 (ATAD2 IC50 = 130 nM, BRD4 IC50 = 16 μM) with nanomolar potency and impressive selectivity over BRD4 (>100-fold). An additional example was compound 28, in which the main naphthyridone core was replaced with a quinolinone core (ATAD2 IC50 = 158 nM, BRD4 IC50 = 4 μM). The crystal structure of 28 bound to ATAD2 showed that instead of hydrogen bonding with Arg1007 from the RVF shelf of ATAD2, the cyclic sulfone makes an interaction instead with Arg1077 on helix 7 and potentially clashes with the corresponding WPF shelf residues on BRD4 (Met149 and W81; Figure 11), imparting selectivity over BRD4. Because compounds 27 and 28 had poor permeability, several analogues were made in an attempt to improve this property. One of these analogues, compound 29 had better permeability at the expense of ATAD2 potency and BRD4 selectivity (ATAD2 IC50 = 316 nM, BRD4 IC50 = 8 μM). Compound 29 was further evaluated and is very selective against other bromodomain family members, except for TAF1(2) and CECR2. As discussed above for CBP and other bromodomain inhibitors, optimizing the interaction with the “WPF shelf” region of ATAD2 (RVF shelf) appears crucial for obtaining both potency and selectivity. While the authors of these ATAD2 publications were unable to identify one optimal molecule in terms of potency, selectivity, and permeability, they did indicate that a subsequent publication would describe a more selective and cell-permeable ATAD2 probe compound.

    CECR2 Bromodomain Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Recently, the SGC has declared a CECR2 (cat eye syndrome chromosome region, candidate 2) bromodomain probe, NVS-1, but they have not yet released the structure.(70) NVS-1 (IC50 = 0.047 μM, ITC Kd = 0.080 μM) was developed by Novartis and is reported to be a highly potent and selective probe that is active in the cellular FRAP assay. However, it is noted that this compound is poorly soluble, so cellular experiments requiring high concentrations may not be feasible.

    SMARCA4 (BRG1) Bromodomain Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    SMARCA4 (SWI/SNF related, matrix associated, actin dependent regulator of chromatin, subfamily A), also known as BRG1, has been implicated in lung cancer and in other tumor types.(71, 72) In addition, SMARCA4 may play a role in sensitivity and resistance to anticancer drugs.(73)
    The SGC has disclosed the SMARCA4 bromodomain inhibitor 30 (PF1-3, Figure 12) developed by Pfizer, but the design of the probe and a description of its optimization has yet to be published.(74) Compound 30 binds with high affinity to SMARCA2/4 as well as to the fifth bromodomain of Polybromo 1, [PBRM1(5)] (ITC Kd of 89 nM and 48 nM for SMARCA4 and PBRM1(5), respectively. In a panel of 15 bromodomains assayed by DSF, only SMARCA2, SMARCA4, and PB1(5) showed significant Tm shifts (ΔTm 6.5, 5.1, and 7.5 °C, respectively). Compound 30 showed activity in a FRAP-recovery SMARCA2 cellular assay. More recently, Vangamundi et al. showed that inhibition of the SMARCA2 bromodomain fails to display an antiproliferative phenotype.(75)

    BRPF1 Bromodomain Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The BRPF1 (bromodomain and PHD finger containing 1) protein is part of the BRPF family that also includes BRD1 (aka BRPF2) and BRPF3. BRPF proteins are a component of the MYST family histone acetyltransferase (HAT) complexes(76) in which they bridge the subunit ING5 and hEAF6 to the HAT-containing transcriptional coactivators, MOZ/MORF.(77-79) While some biological functions have been linked to different subunits of the tetrameric complex,(77, 80) including the BRPF proteins,(81) little is known about the precise role of the bromodomain itself within either the full-length proteins or the HAT complexes. In an attempt to establish a robust target–phenotype correlation and ultimately evaluate the therapeutic potential of BRPF1 bromodomain inhibition, small-molecule inhibitors have been sought. In addition to reports of selective BRPF1 inhibitors, others have disclosed pan-BRPF (BRPF1/2/3) bromodomain inhibitors, each of which selectivity type could prove valuable as chemical tools.

    GlaxoSmithKline BRPF1 Inhibitor

    Identified in the context of a BRD4 drug discovery program, a highly ligand efficient 1,3-benzimidazolone fragment demonstrated promising activity in a BRPF1 assay (IC50 = 10 μM, LE = 0.47) and was selected by Demont et al. as a starting point to develop a inhibitor of the BRPF bromodomain family.(82) After assembling and testing 1,3-benzimidazolone analogues, compound 31 (BRPF1 IC50 = 79 nM) was discovered (Figure 13). Apart from its attractive potency, 31 appears to be selective for BRPF1 over multiple other bromodomains, including BRD4(1) (IC50 > 50 μM). Unexpectedly, selectivity for BRPF1 over BRPF2 (100-fold) and BRPF3 (>1000-fold) was observed. Subtle differences, close to the KAc binding pocket and, more precisely, the substitution of BRPF1 Pro658 by Ser592 in BRPF2 and Asn619 in BRPF3, are believed to contribute to the observed selectivity. The co-crystal structure of 31 bound to BRPF1 reveals a hydrophobic interaction between Pro658 and the 1,3-benzimidazolone, whereas examination of the apo structure of BRPF2 suggests this type of hydrophobic interaction would not be possible (Figure 14). The complex structure confirmed the interaction of the C2 carbonyl with the conserved Asn708 and, through water, with Tyr665 in BRPF1. Additionally, the co-crystal structure revealed that the N1-methyl (piperidine side) is buried in the back of the KAc binding pocket while the N3-methyl (benzamide side) is exposed to solvent. This binding mode is consistent with the SAR data that show a greater loss of potency for the N1-desmethyl (250-fold) than for the N3-desmethyl (8-fold). In a cellular context (BRET assay), compound 31 exhibited a dose–response curve with a 0.98 μM IC50.

    SGC BRPF Inhibitors

    To date, the SGC and their collaborators have reported three bromodomain inhibitors for the BRPF family bromodomains. Two of these, 32 (PFI-4)(83) and 33 (OF-1),(84) are close analogues of compound 31, having the same 1,3-benzimidazolone motif. The third SGC compound, 34 (NI-57),(85) is based on a new quinolinone scaffold (Figure 13). Although biochemical data may suggest a slight potency advantage for 32 (BRPF1 IC50 = 45 nM, ITC Kd = 13 nM) compared to compound 31, the latter has been more extensively profiled and also shows slightly better selectivity over BRPF2/3.
    Compound 33 is classified as a pan-BRPF bromodomain inhibitor based on binding to both BRPF1 (ITC Kd = 100 nM) and BRPF2 (ITC Kd = 500 nM) and, to a lesser extent, BRPF3 (ITC Kd = 2,400 nM). This compound is reported to have >100-fold selectivity for BRPF1 over other bromodomains tested, with the exception of TRIM24 (50% inhibition at 20 μM) and, more importantly, BRD4 (39-fold). In cellular contexts, 33 showed evidence of cellular target engagement at 1 μM in a full-length BRPF1B thermal shift assay and at 5 μM in a BRPF2 FRAP assay.
    Lastly, the University of College London has developed the BRPF bromodomain probe 34. Similar to 33, 34 is a pan-BRPF inhibitor with cellular activity (BRPF1 ITC Kd = 31 nM, BRPF2 Kd = 110 nM and BRPF3 Kd = 410 nM). Interestingly, 34, which shows some structural similarity to the BET inhibitor PFI-1 (40, Figure 18), does not appear to bind significantly to BRD4 yet does interact with the BRD9 bromodomain (32-fold selectivity for BRPF1). An important advantage of having two distinct scaffolds for interrogating the role of pan-BRPF inhibition in human diseases, as in the case of 34 and 33, is that they decrease the likelihood of having the same off-target profile and, therefore, increasing the confidence in the target-phenotype correlation.(86)

    Dual TRIM24 and BRPF Bromodomain Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    TRIM24 (aka TIF-1α, tripartite motif 24 protein) is a multidomain protein characterized by an adjacent PHD finger and bromodomain, as well as by other auxiliary domains, including a RING finger motif. Tsai et al. reported that both the PHD finger and the bromodomain function as a cooperative unit that respectively recognize unmodified H3K4 and H3K23ac on the same histone tail.(87) TRIM24 is known to deregulate the retinoic acid-signaling pathway(88) and to interact with estrogen receptors(87) to promote tumor development. High TRIM24 levels have also been observed in multiple cancer cell lines,(89, 90) and overexpression has been concurrently associated with a poor prognosis in breast cancer patients.(87) In an advance that will help both to understand the complex mechanism by which TRIM24 regulates cancer and to better dissect the biological function of each domain, chemical probes derived from a 1,3-benzimidazolone scaffold have recently been published by two independent groups.

    SGC TRIM24/BRPF Inhibitor

    In 2015, the SGC and their collaborators reported compound 35 (Figure 15) as a dual TRIM24 (IC50 = 430 nM, ITC Kd = 222 nM) and BRPF1 (IC50 = 340 nM, ITC Kd = 137 nM) inhibitor.(91) Although there is meaningful potency against BRPF2 (IC50 = 1750 nM, ITC Kd = 1,100 nM) and BRPF3 (IC50 = ∼7 μM), the selectivity over the other bromodomains tested in a thermal shift assay, including BET family members and CBP, appears to be good. A co-crystal structure of 35 bound to a TRIM24 PHD/bromodomain construct confirmed the binding of the ligand in the KAc channel of the bromodomain, where the 1,3-benzimidazolone moiety forms a canonical hydrogen bond with Asn980 and a water mediated hydrogen bond with Tyr935. In a cellular context (FRAP assay), compound 35 was able to displace the full-length TRIM24 protein from chromatin at 1 μM, but failed to show any effect with the full-length BRPF1 protein under similar conditions. However, when using a construct expressing three tandem copies of the BRPF1 bromodomain, evidence of cellular target engagement was found. When tested against a small panel of cancer cell lines, compound 35 showed only modest cytotoxicity (GI50 > 10 μM). It is unclear whether TRIM24/BRPF1 inhibition simply has little effect on cellular viability, whether the weak phenotype is the consequence of modest cellular potency of the compound or whether testing a larger panel of cell lines would reveal greater effects.

    The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center TRIM24/BRPF Inhibitor

    Concurrent to the SGC work, research conducted by Palmer et al. led to the discovery of 36 (IACS-9571, Figure 15), a more potent TRIM24 bromodomain inhibitor (IC50 = 8 nM, ITC Kd = 31 nM).(92) Having first identified multiple indolinones, tetrahydroquinolin-2-one, and 1,3-benzimidazolone as initial hits, the team eventually concentrated their efforts on the latter series. The SAR revealed a wide tolerance of substitutions around the arylsulfonamide and, therefore, this position was used to modulate physical properties. Alternatively, using the vector offered by meta substitution (rather than the para position on the phenoxy group) increased the potency by about 10-fold. Guided by co-crystal structures, the team then examined 3,5-disubstituted analogues as a strategy to simultaneously target two productive vectors. Indeed, the co-crystal structure of 37 (Figure 16) reveals that these two substitutions could occupy either what the authors referred to as the “upper pocket” (chain A) or the ZA channel (chain B; Figure 16). Also shown in the figures are packing interactions between the ligand in chain A with chain B (Figure 16B) and between chain B and its symmetry mate (Figure 16C). These interactions may render the conformations observed in the structures artifactual, and it is therefore difficult to assess which, if either, is the biologically relevant conformation. This bidirectional design, combined with the introduction of a basic amine on one of the substituents to form a salt-bridge interaction with Asp926, led to a significant increase in potency. More importantly, the cellular activity was improved; 36 demonstrates a TRIM24 EC50 of 50 nM in an AlphaLisa cellular target-engagement assay. While 36 lacks selectivity against the BRPF family, in particular BRPF1 (ITC Kd = 14 nM), good selectivity is observed over other bromodomains, including BRD4 (Kd > 10 μM). In the context of future in vivo studies, the pharmacokinetic profile of this compound was evaluated in mice and appears to be reasonable (clearance approximately half the rate of hepatic blood flow, iv terminal half-life of 0.7 h and bioavailability of 29%).

    BPTF Bromodomain Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Although a highly potent and selective BPTF (bromodomain PHD finger transcription factor) inhibitor has yet to be disclosed, Urick et al. recently discovered a weak BPTF bromodomain inhibitor, 38 (AU1, Figure 17), through 19F NMR screening.(93) Compound 38 (ITC Kd = 2.8 μM) shows modest BPTF activity and appears to be selective for BPTF over BRD4, but potency against other bromodomains is not reported. The authors investigated the effect of 38 in BPTF-mediated gene regulation and found that it does interfere with the MOBKL3 regulatory region, suggesting that the BPTF bromodomain is crucial for gene regulation. Compound 38 may provide a reasonable starting point for developing a BPTF probe; however, the poor ligand efficiency (LE = 0.23) for this compound suggests that it could be a challenging lead to optimize.

    BET Bromodomain Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The influential disclosures of the BET inhibitors 1(15) and 2(17) [followed shortly thereafter by 39 (I-BET151)(94) and 40 (PFI-1)(95)] sparked tremendous academic and industrial interest in inhibitors of the BET family (BRD2, BRD3, BRD4, and BRDT) bromodomains and the phenotypes they elicit (Figure 18). Spurred on by the ever-increasing number of reports relating small-molecule BET inhibition to phenotypes as varied as cancer cell proliferation(96) and suppression of inflammatory response,(97) drug discovery researchers over the last three years have reported far more inhibitors of BET bromodomains than of all other bromodomains combined. Many of the reported compounds have been used as chemical genetic probes to continue to explore phenotypes and understand the molecular role of BET inhibition. BRD4 and the BET family have also been used as a platform to develop new methods of characterizing cellular target engagement. In perhaps the greatest sign of the importance of BET bromodomain inhibition, a few compounds have progressed to human clinical trials in cancer indications, where promising results have been reported.(98) In this section, we present highlights of BET chemical matter, screening methods, and new phenotypes reported since 2012.(19)
    BET inhibitors can be categorized based on their KAc mimic (e.g., triazole, dimethylisoxazole, and pyridone-like), leaving only a few compounds that do not fit into these categories (Figure 19). To a large extent, the seminal BET inhibitors 1, 2, 39, and 40 are archetypical of some of these categories and likely inspired and informed other groups as they explored BET bromodomain inhibitor space. While the KAc binding site of the BET bromodomains is highly homologous to that of other bromodomain-containing proteins (e.g., CREBBP, BRD9, and SMARCA4), selectivity has been achieved in a number of different ways, especially by taking advantage of differences in the gatekeeper and WPF shelf residues.

    Triazole-Derived Binding Motifs

    The first widely recognized BET bromodomain inhibitors reported were the triazole-based diazepines 1 and 2. A closely related compound is 41 (OTX015, Figure 20), the rights to which were acquired in 2012 by OncoEthix from Mitsubishi Tanabe. Differing only in the substituent at the amide side chain from 1 (which itself was identified based on insights from Mitsubishi’s original patent),(16) compound 41 has since been developed for human dosing(99) and has seen application in a number of clinical trials for oncology indications (see below for further discussion). As is evident from co-crystal structures of 1 or 2 bound to BRD4(1), the triazole is a good KAc mimic because of its ability to engage both Asn140 and Tyr97 and to orient a methyl group into the back water pocket (Figure 19A). Combined with thiophene or benzene rings, the diazepine structure optimally positions the pendant chlorophenyl ring to fill space in the hydrophobic region over the gatekeeper. Taken together, these features make an attractive template that has been the inspiration for a number of groups in their efforts to develop different BET inhibitors.
    Perhaps the closest analogues of 1 were described by Concert Pharmaceuticals, whose various deuterated molecules incorporated the heavy atom at key sites of oxidative metabolism to affect plasma exposure by way of the kinetic isotope effect.(100)
    In another example of a related series, Bayer published a patent application describing BET inhibitors that preserved the [5–7–5] fused ring system of the Mitsubishi thienotriazolodiazepines but replaced the dimethylthiophene with an 1,2-dimethyl pyrrole.(101) Some of the resulting compounds, such as 42 [BRD4(1) IC50 = 20 nM, Figure 20] showed growth inhibition in multiple cell lines. The same group also found that potency could be maintained by replacing the amides at the 4-position with heterocycles.(102) Around the same time, Bayer disclosed another series of BET inhibitors that maintain the [6–7–5] fused ring system of 2 but replaced the connecting imine in the azepine with an alkene, as represented by compound 43 (Figure 20).(103) Although no co-crystal structures of 43 have been released, the compound is clearly able to engage in productive binding interactions with the BET bromodomains, as it is potent both biochemically [BRD4(1) IC50 = 20 nM] and in leukemia cells (MOLM-13, EC50 = 120 nM).
    The team at Constellation found that an isoxazole KAc mimetic (originating from an aminoisoxazole fragment identified through a fragment screen) could be merged with the benzodiazepine motif to make highly potent compounds such as 44 [BRD4(1) IC50 = 14 nM, Figure 20]. Compound 44 was active against a number of hematological cell lines (e.g., MV4-11 GI50 = 15 nM), which translated into efficacy when dosed PO QD in a mouse xenograft model.(104) CPI-0610, CPI’s clinical BET inhibitor, is derived from this isoxazolobenzazepine series and its structure was recently revealed at the 2015 AACR annual meeting but has yet to be disclosed in print literature.(105) CPI later reported that BRD4 activity could be maintained and in vivo metabolism reduced even when the carboxamide substituent was pared back to a methyl group.(43)
    Returning to the triazole motif, CPI determined that the acetyl recognition site would tolerate disubstitution at the 4-position.(106) Synthetically challenging compounds like trisubstituted cyclopropane 45 [BRD4(1) IC50 = 500 nM, Figure 20] (and related cyclobutanes and oxetanes) recapitulated the same key interactions as 1 and 2, with the spiro substituent at the 4-position causing no apparent undesirable clash with the binding site.
    In a subsequent report, the same group replaced the imine of the diazepine scaffold with an aniline. The approach generated potent bromodomain inhibitors such as compound 3 [BRD4(1) IC50 = 15 nM, Figure 20].(44) In a crystal structure of compound 3 (Figure 3) bound to BRD4(1), the compound adopted the requisite cup-shaped conformation, allowing it to interact with Asn140/Tyr97 and position the chlorophenyl tail group in the hydrophobic region near the gatekeeper and the border of the WPF shelf. Compound 3 had reasonable metabolic stability and, when dosed orally in mice, reduced IL-6 release in a dose-dependent manner following stimulation with lipopolysaccharide. These in vivo data indicate that it is possible to modulate an inflammatory response through BET bromodomain inhibition.
    CPI reported a different series of triazole-based binders in 2012 in a patent application disclosing substituted triazolopyridazines.(107) A structurally related series based on a triazole fused to a phthalazine body had been previously reported by the SGC but suffered from poor potency and selectivity over the bromodomains of CBP and BRD9, likely because of suboptimal positioning of the WPF shelf binding motif.(57) An example is compound 46 [BRD4(1) IC50 < 500 nM, Figure 20], in which the N-methyl and N-α-methylbenzyl moieties fill the ZA channel and cover the WPF shelf. The biochemical activity of these compounds translated well into MYC mRNA suppression and IL-6 release cellular assays. A group at Boehringer-Ingelheim explored similar compounds with various N-linked saturated heterocycles instead of the urea.(108)
    Workers at Incyte found that the N-methyl aniline group of compounds like 46 could effectively be tied back into a heterocycle and still maintain potency.(109) One such example, 47 [BRD4(1) IC50 < 100 nM, Figure 20], was reported to be active in a myeloma cell line (KMS.12.BM, EC50 < 1 μM).
    In a different approach, a group at Boehringer-Ingelheim incorporated a biaryl motif into the body of their BET inhibitor to cover the top of the WPF shelf, with a short alkyl chain substituent extends from the side of the inhibitor and lies just over the gatekeeper.(110) Resulting triazolopyrazine compounds such as 48 (Figure 20) were quite potent [BRD4(1) IC50 = 9 nM].

    Isoxazole-Binding Motifs

    The Asn140/Tyr97 KAc mimetic that has received the most attention in recent years has been the dimethylisoxazole based on the prototypical 39. Co-crystal structures of dimethylisoxazole-based inhibitors bound to the BET bromodomains show that the oxygen of the isoxazole engages in a hydrogen bond with the NH2 of Asn140, leaving the heterocycle nitrogen poised to interact through water with Tyr97 and the 3-methyl substituent to fill the space of the acetyl lysine substrate (Figure 19B). The 5-methyl substituent remains in close proximity to the Asn140 carbonyl and likely contributes to binding via a noncanonical H-bonding interaction. These ideal interactions, along with the potential of the dimethylisoxazole unit to be incorporated into more modular syntheses than those of the diazepines, have likely contributed to its popularity as a KAc binding motif. Bradner and co-workers recently reported a fluorous-tagged multicomponent approach that yields dimethylisoxazole BRD4 inhibitors, albeit of modest potency and off-target bromodomain selectivity.(111)
    In the design of dimethylisoxazole-based BET inhibitors, some groups have chosen to stay close to the tricyclic core of 39. For example, Aurigene reported a series of imidazoquinoline derivatives typified by compound 49 (IC50 < 200 nM, Figure 21), in which the heterotricycle forms the core of the inhibitor, allowing for imidazole N-linked alkyl- and aryl-heterocycles to serve as the WPF shelf binders.(112) Piramal took a similar approach with compounds like 50 [BRD4(1) IC50 < 300 nM, Figure 21, active in a MOLM-13 leukemia cell line], where the imidazolone of 39 was converted to an imidazolylidene cyanamide.(113) Epigenetix reported modifying the same imidazolone to an oxazolone.(114) Modeling of compounds bound to either bromodomains 1 and 2 of BRD4 allowed Wang and co-workers at the University of Michigan to replace the [5–6–6] core of 39 with a [6–5–6] ring system, resulting in a “γ-carboline” series exemplified by 51 (Figure 21).(115) Compound 51 was biochemically potent against both bromodomain 1 and 2 of BRD4, with Kis ranging from 3 to 25 nM, and it showed activity against the MV4-11 cell line (GI50 = 25 nM). Interestingly, 51 also demonstrated submicromolar activity against the bromodomain of CBP (Kd = 670 nM). Other compounds from the same series showed strong efficacy when dosed at 40 mpk QD PO in an MV4-11 mouse xenograft model (H187 human small cell lung carcinoma) without causing body weight loss.(116) Researchers at Bristol-Myers Squibb also pursued a γ-carboline series, although its substitution pattern suggests that the binding mode in the bromodomain is flipped relative to that of 51. For instance, with compounds such as 52 (Figure 21), the ring nitrogen of the carbazole is used to position benzyl(117) or sulfonamido(118) tail groups that interact with the hydrophobic region of BET. Compound 52 was used to show efficacy in a small cell lung carcinoma mouse xenograft model when dosed PO at 15 mpk BID.
    Moving away from 39, a number of other groups have determined that a tricyclic core is not required to link the KAc mimic with the WPF shelf-binding element. For example, a fragment-based effort reported by the SGC resulted in a series of substituted phenyl-dimethylisoxazoles that demonstrated a BRD4(1) IC50 of 380 nM and submicromolar activity against MV4-11 cells but only ∼2-fold selectivity over the bromodomain of CBP.(35) Researchers at Gilead developed more potent, axially chiral BET inhibitors based on a benzimidazolone core. This is represented by compound 53 (Figure 21), which displayed a BRD4(1) IC50 of 14 nM and a GI50 of 10 nM in a multiple myeloma cell line (MM1.s) known to be sensitive to BET inhibition.(119) In other work from Gilead, quinolines and quinolinones made up the core of the BET inhibitor, with sulfonamide WPF shelf binders at the 6-position.(120) Around the same time, a group at Zenith determined that the dimethylisoxazole could be combined with a benzimidazole body such that N-substituted aryl and aliphatic heterocycles could serve as WPF shelf binders.(121) Compound 54 (Figure 21), representative of this design, demonstrated a BRD4(1) IC50 < 300 nM. Zenith also disclosed BET inhibitors with a 4-substituted benzimidazole core that oriented heteroaryl groups into the WPF shelf.(122) Biaryl compounds from that patent filing demonstrated in vivo activity, including in mouse cancer xenograft studies with OCi-3 leukemia cells and MM1.s multiple myeloma cells in an inflammation model and on the T cell release of various cytokines in T cells. Teams at the SGC(38) and Plexxikon(123) each investigated [5–6] heterocycles as suitable cores but looked at different connectivity relative to the benzimidazoles of Gilead and Zenith (compound 55, Figure 21). Similarly, a team at Beigene determined that 3,3-disubstituted oxindoles could orient aryl heterocycles over the WPF shelf.(124) A representative compound, 56, was potent against the BET family [BRD4(1) IC50 = 8 nM] and demonstrated an EC50 of 34 nM in an MV4-11 cellular assay. Workers at Boehringer-Ingelheim disclosed bromodomain inhibitors with the same oxindole core but with two carbon attachments at the 3-position.(125) They also expanded the five-member oxindole ring to a six-membered ring, creating compounds with a disubstituted dihydroquinazolinone core.(126) Representatives of that series, such as 57 [BRD4(1) IC50 = 34 nM], shown in Figure 21, took advantage of defined stereochemistry to orient the phenyl group into the hydrophobic region. Finally, Incyte researchers used a unique fused tricyclic scaffold.(127) Compounds such as 58 (Figure 21) from this series demonstrated low nanomolar activity against BRD4(1), which translated into submicromolar activity in a cellular assay of MYC transcription repression.

    Pyridone-Binding Motifs

    N-Methyl pyridones and a wide variety of derivatives have been reported by several groups. These bind bromodomains with high affinities because of their ability to recapitulate many of the same interactions with Asn140 and Tyr97 as seen for other scaffolds. For example, co-crystal structures of compounds related to compounds 59, 60, and 61 show the pyridone carbonyl forming a direct H-bond with Asn140 and an interaction with Tyr97 through a water molecule (Figure 19C). The N-methyl group fills the back of the KAc binding pocket.
    In some of the first descriptions of this motif, researchers at AbbVie reported 4-aryl-substituted pyrrolopyridones (with(128) and without(129) substitution on the pyrrole ring) that achieved low nanomolar and even subnanomolar activity against the BRD4 bromodomains. For example, the BRD4(1) IC50 for compound 59 (Figure 22) was measured to be 3 nM, which translated into a GI50 of 1 nM for MX-1 cells. Related compounds have shown efficacy in mouse tumor xenograft models and in in vivo IL-6 release models of inflammation.(130)
    Around the same time, a team at GSK also disclosed fused pyridones that incorporated either a furan [60, BRD4(1) IC50 < 100 nM, Figure 22](131) or thiophene [61, BRD4(1) IC50 < 100 nM, Figure 22] ring.(132) In both cases, the fused pyridone served as the KAc mimetic, and a heteroaryl group interacted with the WPF shelf to position an ether-linked cyclo-alkane or -arene over the gatekeeper residue. Interestingly, some of the pyrrolopyridones reported by AbbVie are more than 150-fold selective for BRD4(2) over BRD4(1). In contrast, GSK’s furopyridone 60 is reported to be at least 100-fold selective for BRD4(1) over BRD4(2). In general, selectivity for either the first or second bromodomain of BRD4 holds true for all the other members of the BET family, suggesting that these compounds can be used to investigate the contributions of individual bromodomains to pan-BET family inhibition-mediated phenotypes and toxicities.
    AbbVie later disclosed that the fused pyrrolopyridone group could be deconstructed to its pyridone core and still retain low nanomolar activity.(133) However, they subsequently found that macrocyclization between the pyridone and the gatekeeper-binding motif afforded more potent compounds, such as 62 [BRD4(1) IC50 = 2 nM, Figure 22], with the cyclization presumably promoting the active conformation.(134) In an in vivo mouse model of inflammation, 62 was found to reduce IL-6 release by 83% following lipopolysaccharide stimulation. AbbVie also found that the pyrrolopyridone could be cyclized onto the moiety that covered the gatekeeper residue while maintaining potency and physicochemical properties consistent with oral dosing. For example, fused polycyclic pyrrolopyridone 63 [BRD4(1) IC50 = 0.7 nM, Figure 22], with a sulfone-substituted phenyl core and fluorophenyl lipophilic binding element, bound BRD4(1) and BRD4(2) equally. Compound 63 reduced tumor growth by 95% after 21 days of QD dosing at 1 mpk in a multiple myeloma mouse xenograft model (animals showed no weight loss).(135)
    Interestingly, the team at AbbVie also found that the methyl group of the pyridone could be moved to the pyrrole nitrogen, accompanied by a corresponding shift of the aryl group.(136) Presumably, the binding mode of the pyrrolopyridone flips to position the methyl group in the same place as the methyl of the acetyl group of the natural substrate. Representative compound 64 [BRD4(1) IC50 = 1 nM, Figure 22] was used in a mouse xenograft model of multiple myeloma, where it showed 79% tumor growth inhibition following 21 days of QD dosing at 2.5 mpk. A related isoindolone series was also explored, in which the pyrrole connectivity was rearranged and the pyridone was partially reduced to form compounds like 65 (Figure 22). The compound proved efficacious in a mouse xenograft model of multiple myeloma, albeit at substantially higher doses than pyrrolopyridone 59.(137)
    A group at Novartis arrived at a different series of N-methylpyridone BET inhibitors.(138) Researchers there took a modular approach in which they coupled a pyrrolopyrrolone with multiple different potential KAc mimetics, including dimethylisoxazole, 1,2,4-triazole, 1,2,3 triazole, and N-methylpyridone. Some of the resulting compounds, like 66 [BRD4(1) IC50 = 85 nM, Figure 22], inhibited growth of MV4-11 and THP cells and proved not only to bind BRD4 but also to be submicromolar inhibitors of the CBP bromodomain.
    Benzimidazoles and their derivatives have also been pursued as the core of potent BET inhibitors. Incyte reported a series linked to the KAc binding group at either the 4-(139) or 5-position(140) that apply a substituted aryl ether as the WPF shelf binding element. Researchers at Boehringer-Ingelheim combined 2-substituted benzimidazoles with an additional nitrogen in the KAc mimetic to create compounds like 67 [BRD4(1) IC50 = 8 nM, Figure 22].(141)
    Finally, workers at Quanticel explored a benzo fusion to the pyridone and arrived at compounds like 68 [BRD4(1) IC50 < 100 nM, Figure 22], which is similar to the AbbVie compound 59.(142)

    Other Motifs

    Although many of the BET bromodomain inhibitors disclosed in recent years have been derived from the seminal work on one of the scaffolds described above, a few drug discovery groups have been successful at developing different chemical matter. Most, but not all, of these compounds satisfy the Asn140/Tyr97 interaction with some sort of carbonyl-based KAc mimetic group, as is the case with 40 that applies a dihydroquinazolinone core. The [6–6] ring system positions a methyl substituent in the back of the KAc pocket and an arylsulfonamide over the gatekeeper, which together lead to its BRD4(1) IC50 of 220 nM. A related oxindole series, with compounds like 69 [BRD4(1) IC50 < 150 nM, Figure 23], was more recently reported by Orion.(143)
    With their disclosure of hydropyridopyrazinone and hydroquinoxalinone analogues, a group at Bayer identified a different class of KAc mimetic motif with a substitution pattern different than that of 40.(144) Structurally similar to reported kinase inhibitor 80 (Figure 26),(145) compounds such as 70 (Figure 23) bind Asn140/Tyr97 through their carbonyl, employing the fused heterocycle as the core and the fluorophenyl group as the lipophilic binding element. The core pyrimidine and aniline linker would be expected to make through-water hydrogen bonds with Gln85 and Pro82 based on the co-crystal structure of 80 bound to BRD4(1).(146) Compounds from this series were active both biochemically and against a panel of leukemia and myeloma cell lines.
    A group at GSK found that the carbonyl group of the KAc mimetic, in compounds like 71, could be moved out of the [6–6] ring system into an acyl moiety while maintaining potency. Optimization of this template eventually led to I-BET726 [aka GSK1324726A, 4-((2S,4R)-1-acetyl-4-(4-chlorophenylamino)-2-methyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinolin-6-yl)benzoic acid].(147) In compounds like 71 [BRD4(1) IC50 < 100 nM, Figure 23], the N-acyl group serves as the Asn140/Tyr97-proximal KAc mimetic, positioning 4-anilino substituents to serve as the lipophilic binding group.(148)
    In further work, Forma Therapeutics also took advantage of an N-acyl KAc mimetic group, employing a substituted tetrahydroquinoxaline core.(149) In compounds like 72 [BRD4(1) IC50 < 100 nM, Figure 23], a substituted pyrazole is positioned to make edge/face interactions with Trp81 in the WPF shelf, and the arylcarbamate interacts with the Ile146 gatekeeper. Analogues containing a tetrahydroquinoline core with 5-aryloxy substituents were also found to be competent BET bromodomain inhibitors.(150)
    In an interesting twist on the diazepine motif of some of the early BET bromodomain inhibitors, the group at Bayer disclosed, in 2014, dihydrobenzodiazepine carboxamides exemplified by 73 [BRD4(1) IC50 = 20 nM, Figure 23].(151) Showing growth inhibition of multiple cancer lines, these compounds likely bind Asn140/Tyr97 through the methyl carboxamide, positioning the 4-methyl substituent in the water pocket and orienting the substituted aryl group as the lipophilic binding element.
    Around the same time, researchers at AbbVie described a series of 3-carboxamide pyrrole-based BET inhibitors.(152) This class of compounds [represented by 74, BRD4(1) IC50 = 78 nM, Figure 23] appears to represent a deconstructed version of AbbVie’s pyrrolopyridone series (65, Figure 22) in which all the main binding elements are conserved. Compound 74 showed activity against a breast cancer cell line (EC50 = 170 nM). A group at Freiburg University identified similar chemical matter in which an acyl moiety serves as the KAc mimetic and contains a substituted acetanilide, although many of these compounds demonstrated only a modest selectivity over other bromodomains, such as CBP.(153)
    At the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, Zhou and co-workers reported a different series of BET inhibitors with unique structural features [e.g., 75, BRD4(1) IC50 < 1 μM, Figure 23].(154) Although the binding mode of these compounds was not described, one could presume they interact with Asn140 via the carbonyl group of the vinylogous amide, which would position the α-methyl group found in the most potent representatives in the water pocket.
    Zenith/Resverlogix have described a number of compounds related to 76 [RVX-208, BRD4(1) ITC Kd = 1,100 nM, Figure 23], now in human clinical trials. Compound 76 is an inhibitor of ApoA1 production that was discovered by phenotypic screening and later determined to act through BET bromodomain inhibition.(155) In this class of compounds, a quinazolinone serves as the KAc binding group and core, interacting with Asn140/Tyr97 via the carbonyl and through-water with the 5-methoxy substituent. Interestingly, 76 has no WPF shelf binding element and, instead, extends a substituted aryl moiety toward the BC loop, where there are substantial differences between the residues in BRD4(1) and BRD4(2). Perhaps because of the different interactions in that region, compounds in this class show greater potency toward all second bromodomains of BET-class proteins than toward the first bromodomains [76, BRD4(2) ITC Kd = 140 nM].(156) The in vitro activity of 76 and its relatives translates well into cellular potency, with many compounds from this series showing activity in assays of mRNA transcript reduction and suppression of IL-6 release following LPS stimulation.
    Noguchi-Yachide and co-workers recently determined that benzoylated adenine derivatives are capable of binding BET bromodomains, although, with the exception of 77 (BRD4(1) IC50 = 430 nM, Figure 23), most compounds from this series displayed only modest potency.(157) No binding mode was reported for this series, but a related series of amino purines has been reported to bind the BRD9 bromodomain through a purine nitrogen.(56)
    Finally, in one of the only examples of a KAc mimetic that is not a triazole, isoxazole, or carbonyl, Zhou and co-workers described a series of diazabenzenes that interact with the conserved Asn via hydrogen bond with a phenol.(158) Compound 78 [BRD4(1) IC50 < 85 nM, Figure 23] applies an extended diazabenzene system as the body with no formal lipophilic shelf binding element. Instead, a co-crystal structure shows that the heteroaryl sulfonamide covers Trp81 and makes water-mediated contacts between a diaza nitrogen and Pro82. Compound 78 was shown to be >25-fold selective over the non-BET bromodomains tested and inhibited cellular IL-6 release (IL-6 EC50 = 4.9 μM), albeit with a ∼100-fold potency shift relative to biochemical assays. These data establish the scaffold as a structurally unique inhibitor of BET bromodomains.

    Biophysical and Computational Identification of BET Inhibitors

    Given the tremendous interest in BET biology and how well-behaved its bromodomains are in biochemical assays, the target has emerged as a platform from which to explore new approaches for the identification of inhibitor starting points. For example, Pomerantz and co-workers have established 19F NMR as a paradigm for finding bromodomain ligands.(159) They found that the bromodomains of BRD4, BRDT, or BPTF expressed in the presence of fluorine-labeled tyrosine or tryptophan led to stable 19F NMR-active constructs with negligible difference in their structure or ability to bind known ligands like 1. Importantly, several of the fluorine resonances shifted measurably upon addition of 1, indicating that they could serve as a readout of ligands binding in the KAc recognition site. It was also found that a second fluorine-labeled bromodomain could be observed simultaneously, which allowed the group to screen for selective binders. In a proof of concept screen, 229 small molecules from a kinase inhibitor set were evaluated at 100 μM against BRD4(1) and BPTF bromodomains, resulting in the identification of novel classes of selective binders for each of the BET and BPTF bromodomains.(93) ITC and fluorescence polarization assays with the wild-type domains yielded Kds and Kis for the new ligands ranging from 0.3–13 μM, demonstrating the utility of this approach.
    Because of the structural rigidity of the isolated bromodomain and the large number of high quality co-crystal structures bound to inhibitors, computational approaches have seemed a natural fit to identify new inhibitors. To that end, Zhao and Caflisch recently reported on a fragment-based docking approach that led to the identification of biophysically validated chemical matter.(160) Using their anchor-based library tailoring technique, they decomposed millions of compounds from the ZINC library into rigid fragments. These were then filtered based on molecular properties such as size and rotatable bonds before being docked into the BRD4(1) bromodomain. Parent compounds that contained at least one of the anchor fragments prioritized through this method were then docked and further evaluated in various molecular dynamics simulations to yield 24 compounds, four of which showed BRD4(1) ΔTm > 1 °C in a DSF assay. Co-crystal structures were reported for two of the compounds [BRD4(1) IC50 ≅ 7 μM], each of which contained a carbonyl that bound Asn140.
    A group teamed with the SGC took a virtual approach to fragment screening, in which they drew upon a library of KAc mimics, fragments based on known bromodomain binders, and topology-based similarity searches for their docking studies.(161) The team took several steps to rule out false positives, including the elimination of poses with compounds in obviously high-energy conformations. This resulted in 250 promising compounds, six of which showed meaningful activity in a biochemical assay and four of which were co-crystallized with BRD4(1). Of the four compounds, two had pyridone-like KAc mimetics, while the others (a quinoline and a triazole) demonstrated novel interactions with Asn140/Tyr97.
    Fragments were also the focus of a study by Shen and co-workers, in which a library of ∼500 compounds with physicochemical properties favorable for drug discovery were docked using Glide into a co-crystal structure of 1.(162) Requiring a hydrogen-bonding interaction with Asn140, the group identified 41 fragments for crystallography experiments and obtained nine co-crystal structures. Among the fragments was a substituted thiazolidinone, a relatively ligand-efficient KAc binding motif that had not been described previously. Subsequent addition of an arylsulfonamide to interact with the Ile gatekeeper residue increased the potency and resulted in compounds like 79 [BRD4(1) IC50 = 230 nM, Figure 23], which displayed weak HT-29 antiproliferative activity.
    Finally, a group from Zenith and Albany Molecular used Glide to screen a database of millions of known compounds in silico against protein models based on the complex of 76 and BRD4(1).(163) Importantly, a water molecule that bridges an H-bonding interaction between most known BRD4 bromodomain ligands and Tyr97of BRD4(1) was treated as a structural water in the workflow. This virtual screen resulted in 153 prioritized compounds representing 82 scaffolds. Subsequent in vitro characterization in a TR-FRET assay identified a number of inhibitors of modest potency, including a quinoxalinone scaffold [BRD4(1) IC50 = 9 μM] that formed a bidentate hydrogen bonding interaction with Asn140 in a co-crystal structure.

    Assessing Target Engagement/Cellular Activity

    Because of the increasing interest in using small molecule inhibitors to explore the phenotypic implications of disrupting BET bromodomains and because of the lack (until recently) of an unequivocal proximal gene or other pathway readouts connected to most of the bromodomain-containing targets, a great deal of work in recent years has gone into developing methods for assessing the cellular activity of small molecule bromodomain inhibitors.
    In one approach, a team at the SGC adapted the concept of fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP) to the analysis of bromodomain binding.(164) They found that when a small section of the nucleus of cells expressing green fluorescent protein linked to either BRD4(1) or BRD4(2) mutated at Asn140 was irradiated with a high power laser pulse, bleaching the fluorescence of all molecules in that section, the fluorescence pattern returned to baseline more quickly in the cells with the mutant construct than the nonmutant one. This faster return to baseline for the mutant construct is consistent with its greater mobility within the nucleus due to a weakened ability to localize to chromatin. Experiments with 1 and 40 using the native construct resulted in recovery half-lives indistinguishable from those of the mutant constructs, providing support for the full engagement of the bromodomain by the inhibitors at the concentrations tested. Importantly, this approach allows for an assessment of whether inhibition of a bromodomain is sufficient to displace a full-length, multidomain protein from chromatin. The data from the SGC suggest that is the case for the BET proteins but not, for example, for CBP. Displacement from chromatin is clearly not the only requirement for a meaningful phenotype, however, because recent reports have implicated CBP bromodomain inhibition in the suppression of the IL-17 cytokine, for example.(39)
    A method disclosed by a team at Constellation and Genentech also took advantage of changes in fluorescence pattern to assess target engagement.(165) As depicted in Figure 24A, cells expressing a Zs-green fluorescent protein linked to a bromodomain display a relatively diffuse fluorescence pattern throughout the nucleus, reflecting the distribution pattern of the bromodomain. Application of a small molecule bromodomain inhibitor was found to disrupt the fluorescence pattern and lead to the formation of highly fluorescent punctate structures or “dots”, presumably due to aggregation of the Zs-green fusions following their displacement from chromatin. Quantification of the formation of the dots at different concentrations of inhibitor allowed for a measure of target engagement.
    In another approach, Promega Corporation developed a bioluminescence resonance energy transfer (BRET) assay that has also proven useful in evaluating the cellular activity of BET and other bromodomain inhibitors (Figure 24B).(166) In their assay, cells express a protein domain of interest [e.g., BRD4(1)] fused to a bioluminescent reporter such as nanoluciferase. In the presence of a tracer construct comprising an acetylated lysine tail coupled to a fluorophore, BRET takes place following irradiation of the system at an appropriate wavelength. Application of a small molecule causes a quantifiable loss in BRET signal, consistent with a disruption of the bromodomain/tracer recognition and cellular target engagement. Importantly, it has been found that the acetylated lysine of the tracer piece can be replaced by a validated small molecule inhibitor, which can lead to a substantial improvement in signal.
    Researchers at Bayer(167) and DiscoveRx Corporation(168) independently took a very different approach toward assessing compound activity in cells based on the ability of a small molecule to bind a target peptide and provide measurable protection from proteolytic degradation in cells. In proof of concept experiments with BRD4, the teams showed that 1 increased the half-life of a truncated bromodomain linked to a readout peptide, consistent with cellular target engagement. The increased levels of the target could be quantified either by β-galactosidase fragment complementation or TR-FRET, either of which was amenable to a high-throughput screening format.
    As with any biological assay, each of these methods described has strengths and limitations, but having multiple approaches available is invaluable to researchers taking a chemical genetics approach toward target validation. Comparable results from orthogonal assays help make an unambiguous determination of target engagement, which has been highlighted as a key element in the meaningful application of a small molecule probe.(169)

    Chemical Biology and Genetic Applications of BET Inhibitors

    The report of potent and selective compounds like 1 and 2, combined with the interest in decoupling the roles of the different bromodomains of BET family members, has led a number of groups to modify BET bromodomain inhibitors into tools for use in chemical biology studies.
    In an example disclosed in 2013, Coferon described compounds that would engage both bromodomains of the BET proteins simultaneously, with the goal of effecting greater release of BET from chromatin and, possibly, a stronger phenotype.(170) Their strategy relied entirely on using other reported bromodomain inhibitors, connected by a variety of linkers at different sites around the molecules, and many of the resulting compounds were very potent. It was not immediately apparent whether the dimeric inhibitors were substantially more potent than their monomeric counterparts (or even whether they were engaging both bromodomains, as intended), but the approach did identify compounds with a MV4-11 GI50 below 30 nM. A later disclosure focused on developing monomeric BET inhibitors that could dimerize spontaneously in aqueous solution to achieve the same effect.(171)
